fields.description: When an instance is launched with --addressing private, metadata service isn't available.  This causes issues with services that are reliant upon the metadata service (i.e. cloud-init).
fields.summary: euca-run-instances --addressing private doesn't have access to metadata service

comments.body:
This is a duplicate of EUCA-2774, access to the metadata service is successful if the CC and CLC are on the same host. The error that occurs is: {code} $ curl http://169.254.169.254/2009-04-04/meta-data/instance-id 404 - Not Found

404 - Not Found: failed to find meta-data/instance-id

{code}

The issue is that when an instance uses private addressing the CLC sees the metadata request as coming from the CC IP. The (public or private) IP is used by the CLC to determine the metadata to serve.

One way to fix the issue is to modify network settings on the CLC and CC. As a proof of concept for this you can change the CLC to add a route to the CC and remove the MASQUERADE from the CC:

# CLC: route add -net 10.88.0.0/20 gw 192.168.51.93 eth0
# CC: iptables -t nat -D POSTROUTING 2

The removed rule is:

{code}
  - 2    MASQUERADE  all  -- 10.88.0.0/20        !10.88.0.0/20 
{code}

With this in place the CLC will see the private IP and serve metadata appropriately.

If we did not want to change networking then we could add a proxy service on the CC to forward the request and include the requestors IP in some way (e.g. as an HTTP header).

In order to properly implement a solution, here, there will have to be some new mechanism in the way that the CC/CLC handle the metadata service that is currently not available.  For the time being, in MANAGED/MANAGED-NOVLAN modes, with the CC and CLC running on different machines, with VMs run with --addressing-private, they will not be able to access the metadata service.

Will link to a new feature request to implement a metadata service subsystem that is resilient to eucalyptus component placement on the network.
Re-assigning this to Chuck for assessment.  Let us know if this is doable for a 3.2.x maint release or will need to be pushed to 3.3.
Hey Chuck, I see this is in progress.   Can you update the ticket with your progress and assessment for 3.2.2?
Just had a quick look at it. Based on Dan's comment I don't think introducing a "new mechanism" for communicating the metadata would be a good thing for 3.2. Suggest this as a candidate for 3.3.
[~awithrow], this was one that we were originally tracking for 3.2.1 but didn't make it.  This is a fairly important one for the field. Any thoughts around this one getting scoped for 3.2.2?
Darren, given the scope of the changes and our maintenance release strategy we need to push this out to 3.3.  If this is untenable then we should discuss our options.
[~awithrow] this can be moved to post 3.2.2 based upon current field exposure to private addressing and priority.
From a field standpoint, this can be pushed to a 3.3.x maintenance release.
[~dstagnaro], thank you for the comment. (Either you read my mind or someone asked you about this one today. :-)
Hey [~chuck], [~hspencer], a fix is scheduled for 4.0, is that correct?
[~viglesias] please test if this is addressed for EDGE mode

Pending Vic's investigation, but EDGE is certainly implemented (and manually tested during development) to permit access to metadata for isntances running with --addressing private.  Caveat is that, in EDGE, the CLC machine *must* have an IP route back to the VM private network for meta-data service to work, across the board (addressing private, or not), since the VM private network is no longer a Euca network (it is just a regular network).
This is working as I expect in EDGE mode when the CLC can reach the instance private IP.
